name: NPR
text: Retail workers on furlough are collecting 42% more on average from unemployment than the grocery workers who are busy stocking shelves â€”  raising questions about fair pay and making it hard for some to return to work. https://t.co/0znxLvzmQC

name: NPR
text: After threatening to pull the convention from Charlotte if restrictions are not eased, President Trump now has Republican governors in other states lining up as alternative hosts. https://t.co/LZCPc0aBMt

name: NPR
text: 2020 looked bright for pianist Nduduzo Makhathini. But when the pandemic hit, he was summoned home for his other role: a traditional South African healer. For @nprmusic, he and his wife Omagugu Makhathini perform "healing sonics" for Alone Together Duets. https://t.co/NQhE7vzsaO

name: NPR
text:
Federal records show OSHA worked for six years to create new rules to prepare for an airborne infectious disease pandemic. The Obama White House formally added it to a list of regulations to be implemented in 2017.

Then President Trump took office. https://t.co/Pv8ffpv1k2

name: NPR
text: School leaders are warning of a financial meltdown that could devastate many school districts â€” and set back an entire generation of students.  https://t.co/F6c6EucvPf

name: NPR
text:
Geologist Keri Belcher applied for unemployment, and after seven weeks of waiting, still hadn't received a single check. She's applied for jobs, with no luck. 

"I guess I'm just a little lost," Belcher says. https://t.co/dnuVxGacmw

name: NPR
text:
All parts of the Nashville music scene were disrupted due to the pandemic, including the work of the producers and songwriters'. 

But for them, it was never "Oh, I guess we'll just have to wait." It was always, "Let's see what we can do." https://t.co/i0lCEneCDH

name: NPR
text: Comedians came together for 2 hours of stand-up to give Muslims around the world some comic relief as they do the unprecedented â€” celebrate Eid al-Fitr in isolation at home, with fewer loved ones than usual.   https://t.co/BVWXrl4FXT

name: NPR
text: An emergency physician discusses what scientists have learned in the last 10 weeks about the coronavirus â€” and what researchers still do not know. ðŸ‘‡https://t.co/GqljIafKfx

name: NPR
text:
Nancy McKinley mixes screwball humor with social criticism in a collection of interlocking stories about two women who work at a mall in Northeastern Pennsylvania.
https://t.co/KvowLlhKNP

name: NPR
text:
The need to get out of the house is real â€” but so are the risks you're taking. 

Experts have rated the risk levels of 14 summer activities, from camping to a night out. The takeaway? The risk level depends on four things: "time, space, people, place." https://t.co/surXlKp5PN

name: NPR
text: Retail workers on furlough are collecting 42% more on average from unemployment than the grocery workers who are busy stocking shelves â€”  raising questions about fair pay. https://t.co/1xKvqDOe10

name: NPR
text:
The number of new coronavirus cases has been going up in Alabama â€” even as the state's governor relaxes restrictions.

One local official says part of the problem is people who "have decided that the pandemic is over."
https://t.co/89GUu0hjEW

name: NPR
text:
Christian Cooper, the black man in Central Park who had the police called on him, says it was "pretty crappy without a doubt." 

But, wonders if the response was "really proportionate."
https://t.co/HGPEMEr30R

name: NPR
text: "People on the spectrum ... sort of feel like an alien being dropped in from outer space, and you can't quite connect properly. Being on stage ... felt like a connection I hadn't been able to establish in any other environment." https://t.co/u9wQwa2icG

name: NPR
text: With the border wall expected to plow through the center of the proud city of Laredo, a remarkably diverse coalition of wall-haters have assembled to fight it. https://t.co/v0r19VTOas
